text: Nnena Kalu wins Turner Prize – impact on Project Ability studio

children.text: Nnena Kalu – Artist Profile & Achievement
Personal background
Born in Glasgow, moved to England as a child
Autistic with limited verbal communication
Age 59 at time of award
Turner Prize win
First learning‑disabled artist to win the prize
Judges' comments: compelling sculptures, beautiful intricate drawings
Significance: broke a stubborn glass ceiling
Artistic style & works
Brightly coloured sculptures wrapped in ribbon, string, card, VHS tape
Drawings of swirling, tornado‑like vortexes
Creative process described as mesmerizing, with chalk sounds
Project Ability – Charity & Studio
Mission and support
Supports artists of all abilities, including learning disabilities
Provides studio space in Glasgow's Trongate
Role in Kalu's career
Hosted her first solo exhibition at Glasgow International 2018
Executive Artistic Director Elisabeth Gibson observed her creative process
Provided visibility leading to further opportunities
Community Reactions
Fellow artists
Kendal (18) – “anyone can be an artist, regardless of struggles”
Andrew (50) – learning disabled, Down's syndrome, inspired and hopeful
Charity leadership
Elisabeth Gibson – thrilled, believes win will reduce judgment
Charlotte Hollinshead – described win as seismic, breaking glass ceiling
Critics & public opinion
Positive: judges praised intricacy and uniqueness
Negative: Waldemar Januszcack (Sunday Times) called work “worst art” and accused virtue‑signalling
Gibson’s response – criticism expected, Turner Prize thrives on controversy
Impact & Inspiration
Motivation for other artists at the studio
Shows that learning disabilities are not a barrier to success
Encourages artists to pursue ambitious goals, e.g., winning awards
Future goals
Andrew expressed desire to win the Turner Prize himself
Broader perception of learning‑disabled artists
Potential shift towards greater acceptance and less judgment
Increased visibility may open more exhibition opportunities
